title: Detection and Geographic Localization of Natural Objects in the Wild: A Case Study on Palms
author: Kangning Cui (City University of Hong Kong), Rongkun Zhu (Xidian University), Manqi Wang (Wake Forest University), Wei Tang (City University of Hong Kong), Gregory D. Larsen (Wake Forest University), Victor P. Pauca (Wake Forest University), Sarra Alqahtani (Wake Forest University), Fan Yang (Wake Forest University), ..., Miles R. Silman (Wake Forest University)
relevance_why: The methods of utilizing aerial imagery and deep learning for object detection may inspire similar approaches in audio-visual applications, specifically in using UAVs for data collection.
background: Detecting and localizing various palm species in dense tropical forests using aerial imagery and advanced machine learning techniques to monitor biodiversity and forest health.
contribution: The study introduces the PRISM pipeline for effective palm detection and mapping, achieving improved accuracy and efficiency in identifying palms in challenging environments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused on structured plantations or specific palm species, often struggling with occlusions and lighting variability in natural settings.
technical_comparison.novelty: PRISM integrates object detection with zero-shot segmentation and calibration methods, enhancing both detection quality and the interpretability of model outputs.

key_innovation: Combines multiple state-of-the-art models and calibration techniques in a unified pipeline tailored for ecological monitoring in complex environments.
real_world_impact: This framework provides significant insights for managing and conserving palm biodiversity while offering a scalable solution that could adapt to monitor other natural objects as well.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.orthomosaic: **Orthomosaic** refers to a composite image created from aerial photographs, stitched together to create a single, geometrically accurate representation of the ground.
